comment._content: Thanks for pointing to that other pic, pellethepoet. It's one of my faves!

comment.author: 51374074@N06
comment._content: my great grandparents x5 are in there, they where first fleeters and i cant go visit them because there is a bloody train station on top of them

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/stephaniebraysmith] Hi StephaniaRose, all of the graves were carefully relocated to other burial grounds throughout Sydney. Unclaimed remains - the vast majority - were relocated to Bunnerong Cemetery, now known as Pioneer Memorial Park. I'm sure you'll find your ancestors there. If they were First Fleeters, it is likely they had already been moved once before, from the old burial ground where the Town Hall now stands, to Devonshire Street above.

comment.author: 49503012504@N01
comment._content:
This would be from Devonshire Street looking North-west  towards the Town Hall?

StephaniaRose: they may be in Newtown cemetery, or the Camperdown memorial park outside the cemetery wall. A lot of bodies from Town Hall and Devonshire street were moved there (by special tram!)

comment.author: 52271725@N07
comment._content:
Are you sure that is the Town Hall? I was thinking that this was the short part of the Anglican section of Devonshire Sandhills that ran along Elizabeth Street, sort of from the Albion Brewery to before Devonshire St as we know it today. I had thought that the impressive tower might be the tower of Sydney University on Petersham Hill meaning that we are looking SW.

State Archives I am hoping to use one of your old DSC images on a Taphophile post on Tuesday. Shall post a link when I have it ready. Thanks in advance ...

comment.author: 49503012504@N01
comment._content: the steeple on the left looks like St lawrence to me...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] AB (or is it AG today?), can we please have a higher-res?

comment.author: 52271725@N07
comment._content:
I have fiddled around with Google a bit and have some more alternatives.

The steeple on the left could be St Laurence (they seem to think it is), and perhaps the turretted building is Horderns on George, but that would put these headstones in about Belmore Park, and I did not think that Devonshire Sandhills went across Garden St/Eddy Avenue. St Laurence now has a crucifix on its steeple but dont know it is had this in 1902.

The other possibility for these two landmarks, is that the 'steeple' is on the Boys High School in what is now Chalmers St (dated 1867). It looks quite similar. And the turretted building could be St Andrews Greek Theology College on Cleveland St. Not sure when this 'church' was constructed. This would locate the headstones clearly within the Anglican section of the old cemetery. They are not elaborate enough to be Roman Catholic memorials.

comment.author: 52271725@N07
comment._content: The St Andrews Greek Orthodox church was constructed between 1848 and 1855 from a design by Edmund Blacket, who oversaw the construction. It started life as St Paul's Anglican Church.

comment.author: 52271725@N07
comment._content: Okay, over to someone with more knowledge. That turret could easily be Hordens when I compare the turret and the style of windows. Which has to make these graves in what is now Belmore Park.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/52271725@N07] My 2 cents - Christ Church St Lawrence on the left; Hordern's old warehouse with the tower (burned down in July 1901 which helps date this photo); photographer was outside the old Sydney Station looking north-ish across Devonshire St with the tram lines (now pedestrian tunnel). Extremely muddling because the area has changed so much, and the Hordern building is not the later big department store. Easier to see on the 1895 interactive map - I think the photo was taken from about the "V" of "Devonshire", looking north-ish - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/52271725@N07] I think you've already worked it all out but I've uploaded a higher res version which might help confirm your thoughts.
-AG

comment.author: 49503012504@N01
comment._content: that settles it...you can read the Horderns sign. Interesting there appears to be a group of mourners at one of the graves, and over the fence a group of (cemetery?) workers relaxing

comment.author: 52271725@N07
comment._content:
Yes,  I agree, even though I am a novice at this sort of thing. The writing is a give-away.  The topography here seems, to my eye, to be similar to that of Belmore Park today. Thank you also AG for the higher resolution. I will use it in my post, please.

One more thing. See the steeple of St Laurence? Immediately below it is a 'white' building, which is about where I thought the Carters'' Barracks was. But I thought these barracks were demolished in the early 1870s. Yet this image of Devonshire Cemetery is thought to be about 1902. I am not convinced of that date, because burials had ceased not long after Rookwood came online in 1867 so why would there be a group of mourners? Unless they were all preparing to move the bodies perhaps? There are also headstones from Devonshire over in Gore Hill Cemetery.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/52271725@N07] The "white building" could be the back of the Police Inspector's or the Benevolent Asylum (www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4819046243/ ). See this 1880 map, which also shows the religious denominations within the cemetery - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3424-sd&rgn=...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Here are some more maps, from the Sydney metropolitan detail series, showing the old Devonshire Street Cemetery. 1887 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367594.html 1895 (2nd ed.) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367595.html It would appear that we are looking at the Wesleyan section, with the Roman Catholic beyond the fence in the distance, and the Congregational to the left, and the Hebrew to the right, just out of sight. And a map from the series showing the buildings between the cemetery and Christ Church. 1888 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367586.html

comment.author: 52271725@N07
comment._content: Thank you, State Records. I used the above photograph in today's blogpost here sydney-eye.blogspot.com.au/2012/08/taphophile-tragics-ear... Thank you Beachcomber & Pellethepoet. I enjoyed the above interactionm and am in awe of your knowledge and research skills. I am planning a post on the Carter Barracks in the near future, where a lot of the above will be integral. I also live very close to John Rae's 'eye in the sky' so plan to do a post of his house, and what he could see way back when. Many thanks.
